Mastriano & PA GOP Plot War On Workers

The GOP‚Äôs Pennsylvania gubernatorial nominee is planning to crush unions if he wins on November 8.

cards.caption: Pennsylvania Republican gubernatorial candidate Doug Mastriano. (David Dermer/Associated Press)

cards.productDescription: In our brand-new 135-page publication exclusively for supporting subscribers, we reveal point by point how a court led by a celebrated ‚Äúmoderate‚Äù like John Roberts has become the most extreme in a century ‚Äî and what can be done to stop it.

sections: Pennsylvania Republican gubernatorial nominee Doug Mastriano is best known for his Christian nationalism, his role in the January 6 Capitol attack, and his dalliances with neo-Nazis. But as we note in

, our reporter has uncovered another skeleton in Mastriano‚Äôs closet: his staunch anti-union agenda, which includes plans to pass a right-to-work bill that could wreak havoc on Pennsylvania unions and the state‚Äôs working class. With polls in the race tightening, it‚Äôs important to spread this information far and wide.

If Republican Doug Mastriano wins the increasingly competitive Pennsylvania governor‚Äôs race next month, passage of aggressive anti-union legislation targeting private and public sector unions is virtually guaranteed.
Mastriano, a state senator who is facing Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro in the November 8 election, is well-known for his

with neo-Nazis. Less covered this election cycle is that Mastriano and his GOP allies are preparing an unprecedented attack on the labor movement in Pennsylvania, via so-called ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù legislation.
In April, when Mastriano was asked if he supported making Pennsylvania a ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù state, he
, ‚ÄúClearly I‚Äôm a supporter of that. And I can actively use my network across the state to pressure my colleagues in the General Assembly to get it done.‚Äù
In the state Senate, Mastriano has consistently pushed back against the interests of workers. Last year, he co-sponsored
that would have gutted Pennsylvania‚Äôs prevailing wage law, which ensures that public projects do not undercut wages in the construction industry. He was also one of just
members of the state Senate to vote against raising the minimum wage to $9.50 an hour in November 2019.

‚ÄúRight-to-work‚Äù legislation is designed to end ‚Äúclosed shop‚Äù arrangements, in which everyone in a unionized workplace is required to join the union and pay dues. Such laws open the door to a financial death spiral for unions, as they are forced to represent free riders without receiving revenue from them.
Mastriano‚Äôs championing of a ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù law is a dagger aimed right at the heart of labor in Pennsylvania, which counts over 690,000 union members, the fourth-highest total of any state.
lead in most polls and has dwarfed Mastriano in fundraising. But some surveys have found a far closer race, with one recent

pollster showing Shapiro with just a two-point lead. Broadly, Democrats are facing a difficult national political environment, and they have suffered years of consecutive losses in rural and western Pennsylvania, thanks to former President Donald Trump‚Äôs success in areas long dominated by Democrats.
that he plans to use the 2022 elections in Pennsylvania as a test case for contesting any result that fails to go his way in an expected 2024 run, adding extra significance to the race.
Together, these factors make the Pennsylvania governor‚Äôs race a momentous one ‚Äî and an election that could ultimately spell trouble for the state‚Äôs working class.

For Denelle Korin, a registered nurse in central Pennsylvania, the race ultimately comes down to her rights on the job and her ability to advocate for her patients. She realized just how much is at stake during a recent trip to Wisconsin which, under Republican Gov. Scott Walker, took away collective bargaining rights for public sector employees in 2011 and implemented ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù in 2015.

‚ÄúI was very used to Pennsylvania law and structure and how unions can and should run,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSeeing what the employees in Madison go through and the rights they don‚Äôt have was just astounding. It was evident how little say they have in the work they do. I met a nurse who was fired for concerted activity for the work that I do often. It made me have a deep appreciation for the rights I have as a union employee.‚Äù
in the 1930s by businessman and conservative lobbyist Vance Muse to erode workers‚Äô collective power.

By mandating ‚Äúopen shop‚Äù union-represented workplaces, where workers get the benefits of union membership without paying dues, ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù laws make union representation financially impossible. If a union does not have enough money to sufficiently represent workers, then more workers are likely to become dissatisfied with the union and resign their membership.
In 2018, the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision in

made all public-sector workplaces open shop. But the push for right-to-work in private workplaces is even more pernicious, due to a key difference: Public employees enjoy the protection of the First and Fifth Amendments in their workplaces, giving them freedom of speech and assembly as well as the protections of due process, while workers in the private sector do not.

This means that it is far more difficult for anti-union employers to discriminate against workers in the public sector on the basis of union membership than in the private sector, where, due to drastic
of the National Labor Relations Board, employers nearly always get away with discriminating against workers on the basis of their activity in the union.
Starting in 2011, with the help of billionaire Charles Koch‚Äôs

, Republican governors have been using ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù laws to implement a massive, coordinated assault on union rights. Since that time, Indiana, Michigan, West Virginia, and Kentucky have adopted ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù laws, in addition to Wisconsin.
Today, there are 28 ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù states ‚Äî and such laws have had a drastic impact on union membership and workplace safety. All of the
18 states for union density are ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù states, and the top 16 states for union density are all states without ‚Äúright-to-work.‚Äù A 2021
found that ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù states have 50 percent more job fatalities than states that allow employers to negotiate a closed shop.
The right-wing push to expand right-to-work has been blocked in some states by voters. Voters overturned Missouri‚Äôs effort to pass ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù at the ballot box in
. Voters in Ohio overturned a suite of attacks on public sector collective bargaining in
, illustrating that when labor issues are actually before voters, even in red states, Americans are likely to support union rights.
A Longtime Goal Of The Pennsylvania GOP

A Mastriano victory in Pennsylvania would deliver a key victory to the right in their war on unions. Unlike Ohio and Missouri, Pennsylvania does not allow voters to veto referendums. So if Mastriano wins, any successful anti-union law passed under his watch would be a done deal, assuming it survives likely legal challenges.
Pennsylvania Republicans first launched an effort to pass ‚Äúright-to-work‚Äù in
, when they controlled the governor‚Äôs office and both houses of the legislature, but their efforts failed due to lack of support from moderate Republicans. They reprised the effort in
, but because Republicans had by that time lost control of the governor‚Äôs office, straightforward attack efforts would have faced the almost-certain veto of Gov. Tom Wolf (D).

to focus their energy at the time on so-called ‚Äúpaycheck protection‚Äù legislation, designed to kneecap public sector unions by making it harder for them to collect dues and create expensive and onerous recertification requirements to allow them to continue representing their members.
The bill passed the Pennsylvania state Senate, but ultimately failed due to a small group of moderate Republicans in the House, who
police unions‚Äô opposition to the legislation. Nearly all members of that group have either already left office or will have left office by the 2023 legislative session.
Mastriano‚Äôs largest donor by far is Illinois billionaire Richard Uihlein, who
to his campaign in August. Uihlein is a
of anti-union causes, providing key funding to foundations that backed the
Mastriano‚Äôs anti-union bona fides have inspired Korin, the registered nurse in central Pennsylvania, to step up her political efforts in the lead-up to the midterms.

‚ÄúI talk to nurses and health care workers in general as often as I can about the elections,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI have tried to demonstrate what I saw and observed in Wisconsin. What would it look like if you couldn‚Äôt have paid time off and paid sick leave? What would it look like if you couldn‚Äôt have bereavement leave? It‚Äôs in our union contract. Do you really think your employer would allow you to have the time you have now? Would they pay you the way they do now? That‚Äôs why I will absolutely be for candidates that stand up for nurses and health care and are absolutely 100-percent against ‚Äòright to work‚Äô in this state.‚Äù
